results.abstract: Are financial advisers trying to part you from your money in ways you don’t understand? Ask them this set of questions.

media.copyright: Matt Nager for The New York Times
media.caption: Natalie Dunston of Denver, whose husband, Lynn, once exchanged credits he earned selling annuities for a diamond ring worth about $3,500, which he gave to her. “The fiduciary rule ultimately comes down to the fact that some people are making a lot of money at the expense of other people who have no idea how much their adviser is getting paid,” Mr. Dunston said.
